choices.B: Configure AWS CloudTrail to invoke an AWS Lambda function for each event that is related to IAM actions. Configure the function to deny the action if the user who invoked the action is not an administrator.
choices.C: Create an SCP that applies to all the AWS accounts to deny IAM actions for all users except for those with administrator roles. Apply the SCP to the root OU.
choices.A: Create an SCP that applies to all the AWS accounts to allow IAM actions only for administrator roles. Apply the SCP to the root OU.
choices.D: Set an IAM permissions boundary that allows IAM actions. Attach the permissions boundary to every administrator role across all the AWS accounts.

questions.question_text:
A company uses AWS Organizations to manage its AWS accounts. A solutions architect must design a solution in which only administrator roles are allowed to use IAM actions. However, the solutions architect does not have access to all the AWS accounts throughout the company.

Which solution meets these requirements with the LEAST operational overhead?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
"C" is the one.
Correct is C
I picked C, but curious why it might not be A.

comments.content: I wonder as well, SCP deny be default, so if something is not allowed, it is denied by defualt. Or am I missing something?
Oh, I guess one should assume that default policy (FullAWSAccess) allowing everything is attached, then it makes sense.

discussion.content: Correct C

choices.D: Configure a custom AWS Config rule to check for AWS KMS encryption on the S3 buckets. Create an automatic remediation script for the rule that will turn on AWS KMS encryption for any noncompliant buckets.
choices.C: Configure the s3-default-encryption-kms AWS Config managed rule. Create an automatic remediation script for the rule that will turn on AWS KMS encryption for any noncompliant buckets.
choices.A: Configure the s3-default-encryption-kms AWS Config managed rule with manual remediation to check for AWS KMS encryption on the S3 buckets. Modify the properties of the noncompliant S3 buckets to turn on AWS KMS encryption.
choices.B: Configure a custom AWS Config rule with manual remediation to check for AWS KMS encryption on the S3 buckets. Modify the properties of the noncompliant buckets to turn on AWS KMS encryption.

questions.question_text:
A company is using many Amazon S3 buckets to hold confidential data. Some of the S3 buckets are riot encrypted. The company wants to use AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer managed keys to encrypt the S3 buckets. The company wants a solution that will detect any S3 buckets that are not encrypted and apply AWS KMS encryption to each noncompliant S3 bucket.

Which solution will meet these requirements with the LEAST operational overhead?

discussion.content: C is the one

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/s3-default-encryption-kms.html

C
By configuring the s3-default-encryption-kms AWS Config managed rule, the solution can detect any S3 buckets that are not encrypted with AWS KMS encryption. The company can create an automatic remediation script for the rule that will turn on AWS KMS encryption for any noncompliant buckets, eliminating the need for manual remediation. This solution is easy to manage and update, as changes can be made to the remediation script and applied to all noncompliant buckets with minimal effort. Option C is therefore the best solution to meet the requirements with the least operational overhead.

Correct C.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/s3-default-encryption-kms.html
D or B

AD
https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2022/07/aws-database-migration-ibm-db2-zos-source/

Selected Answer: AD
AWS Server Migration Service was discontinued on On March 31, 2022 so, option C is incorrect for Windows migration. For DB migration, we need to choose a managed service as per the requirement so, option D is the right choice.
I vote AD

AB
• Migrate the Linux VM with the IBM Db2 database service to an Amazon EC2 instance by using AWS Application Migration Service (CloudEndure Migration)https://aws.amazon.com/products/migration-and-transfer/https://aws.amazon.com/application-migration-service/. This service can also migrate databases that run on physical or virtual servers to AWS. It replicates your source database server into a staging area in your AWS account without impacting performance or requiring any changes. It also converts your source database server to run natively on AWS by applying the appropriate drivers, agents, and configurations. You can then launch your fully functional database on AWS with minimal cutover windows

Selected Answer: AE
AE makes sense

Selected Answer: AB
This is tricky. If there is application that cant be modified uses a db2 it is next to unpossible to just replace it with mysql database. The application will cease to work. 
Therefore we need need to keep DB2 and I go with A&B.
My choice would be different if we should redesign or reconfigure the application to use another database.

comments.content: Point is you might be able to migrate the data but you cannot make the application work with mysql.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
i vote and d

Selected Answer: AD
I say it is A&D.
so, AE seems like correct

Selected Answer: AD
Isn't it A & D?

questions.question_text:
A company needs to migrate two individual applications from on premises to AWS:

• The first application is a legacy custom application that is hosted on a physical Windows server. The application source code is no longer available. The application has little documentation, has hardcoded operating system configuration settings, and is used by an external third party.
• The second application is an IBM Db2 database that is hosted on a single Linux VM that uses network-attached storage (NAS) to store the database data. The company uses this database internally for employee records.

The applications are hosted in a data center that the company plans to decommission in 90 days. Where possible, the company must use managed AWS services.

Which actions for migration should a solutions architect recommend to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Migrate the Windows server with the legacy application to Amazon EC2 by using AWS Server Migration Service (AWS SMS).
choices.A: Migrate the Windows server with the legacy application to Amazon EC2 by using AWS Application Migration Service (CloudEndure Migration).
choices.D: Migrate the IBM Db2 database data to Amazon RDS for MySQL by using AWS Database Migration Service (AWS DMS) and the AWS Schema Conversion Tool replication agent.
choices.B: Migrate the Linux VM with the IBM Db2 database service to an Amazon EC2 instance by using AWS Application Migration Service (CloudEndure Migration).
choices.E: Migrate the IBM Db2 database data to Amazon RDS for MySQL by using AWS DataSync and the AWS Schema Conversion Tool data extraction agent.

discussion.content:
A
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/AuroraUserGuide/rds-proxy.html

comments.content: AWS Secrets Manager is used but rds proxy is needed for oversubscription...

discussion.content:
Answer is: A
Based on link provided by ggrodskiy
Answer def A

Selected Answer: A
The answer is definitely A.

questions.question_text:
A solutions architect needs to improve an application that is hosted in the AWS Cloud. The application uses an Amazon Aurora MySQL DB instance that is experiencing overloaded connections. Most of the application's operations insert records into the database. The application currently stores credentials in a text-based configuration file.

The solutions architect needs to implement a solution so that the application can handle the current connection load. The solution must keep the credentials secure and must provide the ability to rotate the credentials automatically on a regular basis.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

choices.C: Create an Aurora Replica. Store the connection credentials as a secret in AWS Secrets Manager.
choices.B: Deploy an Amazon RDS Proxy layer in front of the DB instance. Store the connection credentials in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store.
choices.D: Create an Aurora Replica. Store the connection credentials in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store.
choices.A: Deploy an Amazon RDS Proxy layer in front of the DB instance. Store the connection credentials as a secret in AWS Secrets Manager.
